Pre-Game Insights: The St. Louis Cardinals and Milwaukee Brewers meet Monday in MLB action from American Family Field. Here’s a St. Louis Cardinals vs Milwaukee Brewers prediction. This will be the first installment in a three-game series. We will look at this from a betting perspective and determine the best Cardinals vs Brewers pick. We will examine: The St. Louis Cardinals recent form and player performance The Milwaukee Brewers recent form and player performance HOT MLB CAPPERS Mitch Wilson Wayne Scott Jay Yang Ron Romanelli CD Sports Recent betting trends and streaks involving the St. Louis Cardinals Recent betting trends and streaks involving the Milwaukee Brewers Recent betting trends in games played between the Cardinals and Brewers A summary that ties it all together and produces a favorable betting outcome for the Cardinals vs Brewers game

The Cardinals took on the New York Yankees in their weekend set. St. Louis split the first two 6-3 (loss) and 6-5 (win). In the rubber match the Cardinals managed 21 hits in a 14-7 win. Miles Mikolas went 4.0 frames in the start with three earned runs. As a starter for Monday, the Cardinals will send out Andre Pallante. So far Pallante is 6-6 with a 3.80 ERA in 24 games (15 starts). Pallante is 16-12 with a 3.79 career ERA in 133 games (25 starts).

Over on the Brewers’ side, they played the Cincinnati Reds in their last series. Milwaukee won 5-4, 14-0, and 5-4 in the first three. In the finale, the Brewers took a tough loss 4-3 in 11 innings. Starting pitcher Tobias Myers had 5.2 innings with two earned runs. In the starting pitcher slot Monday the Brewers will go with Freddy Peralta. This year Peralta is 9-7 with a 3.70 ERA over 27 starts. Peralta is 51-34 with a career 3.80 ERA in 173 games (124 starts).

Five of the Brewers' last six day games against NL Central opponents have gone UNDER the total runs line. Eight of the Cardinals' last 10 day games against National League opponents have gone UNDER the total runs line. The 'Inning 1 UNDER 0.5 runs' market has hit in each of the Cardinals' last four day games against National League opponents.
